Christofer, only the nodes in the substrate need be fixed.  You can 
allow =
HyperNEAT to determine how to connect them by imposing a 
threshold on the =
output of the CPPN below which the connection is 
not expressed in the subs=
trate.

To get hidden nodes it is correct that you need to include them in =

the geometry in some way.  

I am not sure however what your suggested inp=
ut vector means to the 
CPPN:

(input cube(t0), hidden cube(t1), single out=
put node(t2))

Are you saying that you will input 3 coordinates at once?  I=
t's 
likely I'm just misunderstanding but in general I think it only 
makes=
 sense to input 2 coordinates (the source and target nodes) to 
get the con=
nection weight between them.

Note that one idea that has worked for us wit=
h hidden nodes it to 
have two outputs on the CPPN: One output is for conne=
ctions between 
the input and hidden nodes, and the other is for connection=
s between 
hidden nodes and the output.  

Of course, there are many possib=
le variations.

ken

<c=
hristofer_fransson@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Peter,
> 
> That means that I have to=
 define a fixed network with hidden nodes 
> from the beginning. The CPPN e=
volves, the phenotype is fixed.
> 
> While only input and output nodes have=
 meaningful coordinates I 
> could take a copy of my "input cube" and have =
that as hidden 
network.
> Then I just add a time dimension to the nodes.
>=
 
> The input vector to the CPPN will include 
> (input cube(t0), hidden cu=
be(t1), single output node(t2))
> 
> Thanks,
> Christofer
> 
>

at@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski"

> Hi Christofer,

> > The answer is yes, you can have any topology with=
 HyperNEAT. You 
> > query the CPPN for every possible "from -> to" connect=
ion in the 
> > substrate. But you can disallow input neurons receiving inc=
oming 
> > connections. 
> > 
> > Peter
> >

m, "christofer_fransson"

r all,

 and 
> output

artesian 
> x,y,z 
> > > space.

ate generates a hypercube like 
> > > phenotype network that is applied to =
the problem.

ut sensors 
and 
> 1 
> > > output sensor.  
> > >

 the phenotype generated can be recurrent. 
The 
> > > reason is that I bel=
ieve that recurrent network outperforms

etworks in time series applications.

lace the food-gathering experiment in

egards,
